elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0005">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="spar0025" view="all">An In(III)-based metal-organic framework (<ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>) can selectively absorb cationic dyes in DMF even in the presence of other organic dyes, and has the higher adsorption capacity.</ce:simple-para><ce:simple-para id="spar0030" view="all">
<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="fig0025">
<ce:link locator="fx1" xlink:href="pii:S100184171830127X/fx1" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title id="sect0010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="spar0035" view="all">In this paper, a new anionic metal-organic framework, [In(PBPTTBA)][(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>) has been synthesized through the reaction of tetratopic acid ligand with double Lewis pyridine sites, 4,4′,4″,4‴-(4,4′-(1,4-phenylene)bis(pyridine-6,4,2-triyl)) tetrabenzoic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>PBPTTBA) and In(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and fully characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), infrared spectroscopy (IR), and elemental analysis (EA). <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> can be used as an efficient adsorbent for the selective removal of organic cationic dyes in <ce:italic>N,N</ce:italic>′-dimethylformamide (DMF) solution. The adsorption capacities of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> toward methylene blue and crystal violet at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K can reach 1119<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg/g and 832<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg/g, respectively. Moreover, the adsorbed dyes can be released in the DMF solution of LiNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> gradually.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

An In(III)-based metal-organic framework (BUT-29) can selectively absorb cationic dyes in DMF even in the presence of other organic dyes, and has the higher adsorption capacity.

      

Abstract

In this paper, a new anionic metal-organic framework, [In(PBPTTBA)][(CH3)2NH2] (BUT-29) has been synthesized through the reaction of tetratopic acid ligand with double Lewis pyridine sites, 4,4',4",4‴-(4,4'-(1,4-phenylene)bis(pyridine-6,4,2-triyl)) tetrabenzoic acid (H4PBPTTBA) and In(NO3)2 ⋅5H2O and fully characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), infrared spectroscopy (IR), and elemental analysis (EA). BUT-29 can be used as an efficient adsorbent for the selective removal of organic cationic dyes in N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF) solution. The adsorption capacities of BUT-29 toward methylene blue and crystal violet at 298K can reach 1119mg/g and 832mg/g, respectively. Moreover, the adsorbed dyes can be released in the DMF solution of LiNO3 gradually.

elements.content: <ce:para id="par0005" view="all">Dyes are widely used in many industrial manufacturing processes, such as textiles, plastics, paper, printing, and so on. However, the industrial wastewater containing dyes molecules are usually discharged into water directly without purification, leading to serious water pollution. In addition, most dyes molecules are immune toward light and oxidation so that they are difficult to degrade in nature . Therefore, the removal of dyes from water is essential. Till now, the removal of organic dyes from water is mainly based on traditional methods such as photocatalysis degradation  and membrane separation . Compared with the above-mentioned methods, the adsorption technology based on physical absorption is more promising because of its low energy-cost and user-friendly control. As a new class of porous materials, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), formed by organic ligands and inorganic nodes through coordination bond have been intensively investigated for many applications such as gas storage/separation , solid separation , ion exchange , catalysis  and sensing , due to their advantages of ultrahigh porosity, high surface area, and tunable functionalities . Specifically, as many published works showed that MOFs have shown excellent performances in the removal of dyes .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Dyes are widely used in many industrial manufacturing processes, such as textiles, plastics, paper, printing, and so on. However, the industrial wastewater containing dyes molecules are usually discharged into water directly without purification, leading to serious water pollution. In addition, most dyes molecules are immune toward light and oxidation so that they are difficult to degrade in nature . Therefore, the removal of dyes from water is essential. Till now, the removal of organic dyes from water is mainly based on traditional methods such as photocatalysis degradation  and membrane separation . Compared with the above-mentioned methods, the adsorption technology based on physical absorption is more promising because of its low energy-cost and user-friendly control. As a new class of porous materials, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), formed by organic ligands and inorganic nodes through coordination bond have been intensively investigated for many applications such as gas storage/separation , solid separation , ion exchange , catalysis  and sensing , due to their advantages of ultrahigh porosity, high surface area, and tunable functionalities . Specifically, as many published works showed that MOFs have shown excellent performances in the removal of dyes .

elements.content: <ce:para id="par0010" view="all">Ionic MOFs (I-MOFs) is a unique subclass of MOFs and consists of charged frameworks and extra-framework counter ions . Strong electrostatic interactions between the charged framework and guest molecules are beneficial to increase the adsorption capacity and improve the efficiency of separation processes. Since organic dyes are divided into electrically positive, negative, and neutral charged ones, I-MOFs have been considered as promising candidates for selective adsorption and separation of organic dyes .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Ionic MOFs (I-MOFs) is a unique subclass of MOFs and consists of charged frameworks and extra-framework counter ions . Strong electrostatic interactions between the charged framework and guest molecules are beneficial to increase the adsorption capacity and improve the efficiency of separation processes. Since organic dyes are divided into electrically positive, negative, and neutral charged ones, I-MOFs have been considered as promising candidates for selective adsorption and separation of organic dyes .

elements.content: <ce:para id="par0015" view="all">In this work, a tetratopic acid ligand with double Lewis pyridine sites, 4,4′,4″,4′″-(4,4′-(1,4-phenylene)bis(pyridine-6,4,2-triyl)) tetrabenzoic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>PBPTTBA) has been designed and synthesized. The assembly of H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>PBPTTBA with In(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>∙5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in DMF yielded a new anionic MOF, [In(PBPTTBA)][(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>, where BUT<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Beijing University of Technology). <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> can rapidly and selectively adsorb organic cationic dyes including acriflavine hydrochloride (AH), acridine red (AR), safranine O (SO), methylene blue (MB), crystal violet(CV) and rhodamine 6G (R6G) through an ion-exchange process. Organic anionic and neutral dyes such as congo red (CR), orange G, naphthol yellow S (NYS), orange II, acid fuchsin (AF), methyl orange (MO), methyl yellow (MY), tartrazine, and isatin cannot be adsorbed by <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>. Furthermore, adsorption isotherms measured at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K demonstrate that the maximum adsorption amounts of MB and CV in <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> are 1119 and 832<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg/g, respectively, and <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> could be fully reused after washing with DMF solution of LiNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> several times. These results indicate that <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> is promising adsorbents for efficient capture of MB and CV from waste water.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this work, a tetratopic acid ligand with double Lewis pyridine sites, 4,4',4",4'"-(4,4'-(1,4-phenylene)bis(pyridine-6,4,2-triyl)) tetrabenzoic acid (H4PBPTTBA) has been designed and synthesized. The assembly of H4PBPTTBA with In(NO3)2∙5H2O in DMF yielded a new anionic MOF, [In(PBPTTBA)][(CH3)2NH2] (BUT-29, where BUT=Beijing University of Technology). BUT-29 can rapidly and selectively adsorb organic cationic dyes including acriflavine hydrochloride (AH), acridine red (AR), safranine O (SO), methylene blue (MB), crystal violet(CV) and rhodamine 6G (R6G) through an ion-exchange process. Organic anionic and neutral dyes such as congo red (CR), orange G, naphthol yellow S (NYS), orange II, acid fuchsin (AF), methyl orange (MO), methyl yellow (MY), tartrazine, and isatin cannot be adsorbed by BUT-29. Furthermore, adsorption isotherms measured at 298K demonstrate that the maximum adsorption amounts of MB and CV in BUT-29 are 1119 and 832mg/g, respectively, and BUT-29 could be fully reused after washing with DMF solution of LiNO3 several times. These results indicate that BUT-29 is promising adsorbents for efficient capture of MB and CV from waste water.

elements.content: <ce:para id="par0020" view="all">Solvothermal reaction of H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>PBPTTBA and In(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>∙5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in the presence of HBF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> as competing reagents in DMF at 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h yielded rhombic shaped crystals of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>. Its phase purity has been characterized by PXRD. As shown in Fig. S3 (Supporting information), the experimental PXRD pattern match well with the one simulated from the single-crystal data, indicating that <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> is in the pure phase. The TGA plot of the prepared sample of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> is showed in Fig. S1 in Supporting information, confirming that <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> is stable up to <ce:italic>ca.</ce:italic> 370<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. In the FT-IR spectra of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>, slight blue shifts of carbonyl group characteristic bands compared with corresponding ligands were observed, illustrating the metal coordination of carboxylate groups in these ligands (Fig. S2 in Supporting information).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Solvothermal reaction of H4PBPTTBA and In(NO3)2∙5H2O in the presence of HBF4 as competing reagents in DMF at 120°C for 48h yielded rhombic shaped crystals of BUT-29. Its phase purity has been characterized by PXRD. As shown in Fig. S3 (Supporting information), the experimental PXRD pattern match well with the one simulated from the single-crystal data, indicating that BUT-29 is in the pure phase. The TGA plot of the prepared sample of BUT-29 is showed in Fig. S1 in Supporting information, confirming that BUT-29 is stable up to ca. 370°C. In the FT-IR spectra of BUT-29, slight blue shifts of carbonyl group characteristic bands compared with corresponding ligands were observed, illustrating the metal coordination of carboxylate groups in these ligands (Fig. S2 in Supporting information).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="par0025" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> crystallizes in an orthorhombic chiral space group of <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>. In the structure of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>, the In<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> ion adopts a tetrahedral linkage geometry through coordinating to eight O atoms from four carboxylate groups of four different PBPTTBA<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligands (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig0005"></ce:float-anchor>a). The In-O distances are in the range of 2.2617(1) Å to 2.2905(1) Å, being comparable to those of reported indium complexes . As shown in c, the carboxylate groups in PBPTTBA<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand exhibit chelating coordination mode, with each one coordinates to one In<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> ion. Thus, one In<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> connect to four PBPTTBA<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligands and one PBPTTBA<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand connect to four In<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> atoms to form a 3D framework with one dimensional (1D) rhombic channel, the edge length of which is 16.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (atom to atom distance). Furthermore, two such frameworks are mutually interpenetrated (d). After removal of free solvent molecules, the total solvent-accessible volume of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> is estimated to be 71.3% by <ce:italic>PLATON</ce:italic>. From the topological viewpoint, each In(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> node and PBPTTBA<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand can be viewed as 4-connected nodes, the 3D structure of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> can thus be simplified as a 4,4-c net with the point symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>), corresponding to a <ce:italic>Pts</ce:italic>-type topology. It should be noted that in the framework of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>, every In<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> atom connect with four carboxylic groups, thus, in its pore, there should exist counter-cations to balance the charge of the framework. However, due to the disordered nature, these counter-cations could not be identified through single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. We speculate that these counter-cations should be (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, which is a common by-product in the solvothermal reaction when DMF was used as solvent. EA analysis was then carried out, which showed extra N content inside the pore, which implied the presence of (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>. Furthermore, in the TGA curve of the as-synthesized <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>, there exist a 7.1% weight loss between 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 340<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which is well corresponding to the presence of one (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion per formula (Fig. S1).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals BUT-29 crystallizes in an orthorhombic chiral space group of C2/c. In the structure of BUT-29, the InIII ion adopts a tetrahedral linkage geometry through coordinating to eight O atoms from four carboxylate groups of four different PBPTTBA4- ligands ( a). The In-O distances are in the range of 2.2617(1) Å to 2.2905(1) Å, being comparable to those of reported indium complexes . As shown in c, the carboxylate groups in PBPTTBA4- ligand exhibit chelating coordination mode, with each one coordinates to one InIII ion. Thus, one InIII connect to four PBPTTBA4- ligands and one PBPTTBA4- ligand connect to four InIII atoms to form a 3D framework with one dimensional (1D) rhombic channel, the edge length of which is 16.8Å (atom to atom distance). Furthermore, two such frameworks are mutually interpenetrated (d). After removal of free solvent molecules, the total solvent-accessible volume of BUT-29 is estimated to be 71.3% by PLATON. From the topological viewpoint, each In(COO)4 node and PBPTTBA4- ligand can be viewed as 4-connected nodes, the 3D structure of BUT-29 can thus be simplified as a 4,4-c net with the point symbol of (42 ×84), corresponding to a Pts-type topology. It should be noted that in the framework of BUT-29, every InIII atom connect with four carboxylic groups, thus, in its pore, there should exist counter-cations to balance the charge of the framework. However, due to the disordered nature, these counter-cations could not be identified through single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. We speculate that these counter-cations should be (CH3)2NH2+, which is a common by-product in the solvothermal reaction when DMF was used as solvent. EA analysis was then carried out, which showed extra N content inside the pore, which implied the presence of (CH3)2NH2+. Furthermore, in the TGA curve of the as-synthesized BUT-29, there exist a 7.1% weight loss between 200°C and 340°C, which is well corresponding to the presence of one (CH3)2NH2+ ion per formula (Fig. S1).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="par0030" view="all">Based on the large rhombic channels and cationic framework of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>, we sought to explore its application in the removal of organic dyes. Fifteen dyes including AH, AR, SO, MB, CV, R6G, CR, orange G, NYS, orange II, AF, MO, MY, Tartrazine, and Isatin were checked. Freshly prepared <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> was well activated and then immersed in DMF solutions of these dyes at room temperature. The adsorption abilities of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> toward these dyes were determined by UV–vis spectroscopy. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig0010"></ce:float-anchor>a–d and Figs. S4 (Supporting information), nearly all the cationic dyes can be removed within 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min, while the anionic and neutral dyes could not be absorbed. To future demonstrate the selective adsorption of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> toward cationic dyes, the MOF samples were soaked in the binary mixtures of MB/MO, MB/RB with the concentration ratio is 50/50, respectively. The results were as expected: only the MB was absorbed by the <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> in the solution mixture and the solutions exhibited the color of MO or RB at last and the color of the <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> changed from yellow to blue (inset photograph of e and f). Moreover, compared to other absorbents using a few days, the absorption rate of cationic dyes by <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> was really fast, and nearly 100% of dye molecules can be absorbed within 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min. The high adsorption rate is attributed to the large size of the cage windows (12.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and negative charged framework.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Based on the large rhombic channels and cationic framework of BUT-29, we sought to explore its application in the removal of organic dyes. Fifteen dyes including AH, AR, SO, MB, CV, R6G, CR, orange G, NYS, orange II, AF, MO, MY, Tartrazine, and Isatin were checked. Freshly prepared BUT-29 was well activated and then immersed in DMF solutions of these dyes at room temperature. The adsorption abilities of BUT-29 toward these dyes were determined by UV-vis spectroscopy. As shown in  a-d and Figs. S4 (Supporting information), nearly all the cationic dyes can be removed within 15min, while the anionic and neutral dyes could not be absorbed. To future demonstrate the selective adsorption of BUT-29 toward cationic dyes, the MOF samples were soaked in the binary mixtures of MB/MO, MB/RB with the concentration ratio is 50/50, respectively. The results were as expected: only the MB was absorbed by the BUT-29 in the solution mixture and the solutions exhibited the color of MO or RB at last and the color of the BUT-29 changed from yellow to blue (inset photograph of e and f). Moreover, compared to other absorbents using a few days, the absorption rate of cationic dyes by BUT-29 was really fast, and nearly 100% of dye molecules can be absorbed within 10min. The high adsorption rate is attributed to the large size of the cage windows (12.4×7.1Å) and negative charged framework.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="par0035" view="all">In order to verify whether the absorption process toward cationic dyes is caused by ionic interactions between the cationic dye and framework, dye-releasing experiments were performed both in pure DMF and a saturated DMF solution of LiNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, respectively. The release process was monitored through UV–vis spectroscopy. The results demonstrate that the cationic dye molecules in MB@<ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> and CV@<ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> can be gradually released in the presence of LiNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, whereas they are hardly released without LiNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig0015"></ce:float-anchor>). These results suggest that the absorption can be assigned to the ionic interaction of the dyes with the anionic framework. In addition, the absorbed dyes can be released within 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min (c and d).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In order to verify whether the absorption process toward cationic dyes is caused by ionic interactions between the cationic dye and framework, dye-releasing experiments were performed both in pure DMF and a saturated DMF solution of LiNO3, respectively. The release process was monitored through UV-vis spectroscopy. The results demonstrate that the cationic dye molecules in MB@BUT-29 and CV@BUT-29 can be gradually released in the presence of LiNO3, whereas they are hardly released without LiNO3 ( ). These results suggest that the absorption can be assigned to the ionic interaction of the dyes with the anionic framework. In addition, the absorbed dyes can be released within 20min (c and d).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="par0040" view="all">In the above experiments, it was showed that MB and CV can be completely adsorbed within 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min and 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min in <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>, respectively (a and c). Thus, we further explored the adsorption isotherms of MB and CV in <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig0020"></ce:float-anchor>a, the maximum adsorption amounts of MB and CV in <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> are 1119 and 832<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg/g, respectively. These values are comparable and even higher than those in other porous materials reported so far (Table S2 in Supporting information). In addition, we further measured the of FT-IR spectra of MB loaded <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> and found the appearance of an extra characteristic peak in the wavenumber of 1323<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, which should be the stretching vibration peak of C-N bond of MB molecules, indicating that MB molecules are indeed adsorbed into the pores of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> (Fig. S5 in Supporting information). The superior performances of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> in MB and CV adsorptions could be ascribed to their large specific surface areas, suitable pore size, as well as the ionic interactions between the cationic dye and anionic framework structure of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>. Moreover, Langmuir  and Freundlich  models were used to fit and examine above adsorption isotherms respectively. The related parameters are given in Figs. S6 and S7 in Supporting information. Obviously, the data are well fitted by the Langmuir model, indicating a homogeneous and monolayer adsorption occurring in <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> with a finite number of identical sites.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the above experiments, it was showed that MB and CV can be completely adsorbed within 6min and 4min in BUT-29, respectively (a and c). Thus, we further explored the adsorption isotherms of MB and CV in BUT-29 at 298K. As shown in  a, the maximum adsorption amounts of MB and CV in BUT-29 are 1119 and 832mg/g, respectively. These values are comparable and even higher than those in other porous materials reported so far (Table S2 in Supporting information). In addition, we further measured the of FT-IR spectra of MB loaded BUT-29 and found the appearance of an extra characteristic peak in the wavenumber of 1323cm-1, which should be the stretching vibration peak of C-N bond of MB molecules, indicating that MB molecules are indeed adsorbed into the pores of BUT-29 (Fig. S5 in Supporting information). The superior performances of BUT-29 in MB and CV adsorptions could be ascribed to their large specific surface areas, suitable pore size, as well as the ionic interactions between the cationic dye and anionic framework structure of BUT-29. Moreover, Langmuir  and Freundlich  models were used to fit and examine above adsorption isotherms respectively. The related parameters are given in Figs. S6 and S7 in Supporting information. Obviously, the data are well fitted by the Langmuir model, indicating a homogeneous and monolayer adsorption occurring in BUT-29 with a finite number of identical sites.

elements.content: <ce:para id="par0045" view="all">In order to reduce the cost, reusability of an adsorbent is important for its practical applications. To explore the reusability of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>, the MOF sample after CV adsorption was regenerated by dispersing it in saturated DMF solution of LiNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, and then, the regenerated MOF again used to absorb CV. As shown in b, after 4 repeated cycles, <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> almost regained its initial adsorption capacities toward CV, demonstrating its high stability and good reusability. In addition, as confirmed from PXRD pattern, <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> retained crystallinity after cyclic tests (Fig. S3).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In order to reduce the cost, reusability of an adsorbent is important for its practical applications. To explore the reusability of BUT-29, the MOF sample after CV adsorption was regenerated by dispersing it in saturated DMF solution of LiNO3, and then, the regenerated MOF again used to absorb CV. As shown in b, after 4 repeated cycles, BUT-29 almost regained its initial adsorption capacities toward CV, demonstrating its high stability and good reusability. In addition, as confirmed from PXRD pattern, BUT-29 retained crystallinity after cyclic tests (Fig. S3).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="par0050" view="all">In summary, a new In(III)-based MOF, <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>, has been designed, synthesized, and used in the selective adsorption of organic cationic dyes in DMF solution. <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> has a 3D framework with one dimensional (1D) rhombic channel, which is occupied by (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> counter ions. <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> can be used as an excellent candidate for the selective adsorption of organic cationic dyes and its maximum adsorption amounts toward MB and CV are 1119<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg/g and 832<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg/g, respectively, comparable or higher than those in other porous materials reported so far. The adsorption isotherms of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> toward MB and CV can be fitted by the Langmuir model, indicating a homogeneous and monolayer adsorption process. In addition, <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> can be fully reused after washing with DMF solution of LiNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> several times.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, a new In(III)-based MOF, BUT-29, has been designed, synthesized, and used in the selective adsorption of organic cationic dyes in DMF solution. BUT-29 has a 3D framework with one dimensional (1D) rhombic channel, which is occupied by (CH3)2NH2 2+ counter ions. BUT-29 can be used as an excellent candidate for the selective adsorption of organic cationic dyes and its maximum adsorption amounts toward MB and CV are 1119mg/g and 832mg/g, respectively, comparable or higher than those in other porous materials reported so far. The adsorption isotherms of BUT-29 toward MB and CV can be fitted by the Langmuir model, indicating a homogeneous and monolayer adsorption process. In addition, BUT-29 can be fully reused after washing with DMF solution of LiNO3 several times.

<ce:section-title id="sect0005">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="spar0025" view="all">An In(III)-based metal-organic framework (<ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>) can selectively absorb cationic dyes in DMF even in the presence of other organic dyes, and has the higher adsorption capacity.</ce:simple-para><ce:simple-para id="spar0030" view="all">
<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="fig0025">
<ce:link locator="fx1" xlink:href="pii:S100184171830127X/fx1" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title id="sect0010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="spar0035" view="all">In this paper, a new anionic metal-organic framework, [In(PBPTTBA)][(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>) has been synthesized through the reaction of tetratopic acid ligand with double Lewis pyridine sites, 4,4′,4″,4‴-(4,4′-(1,4-phenylene)bis(pyridine-6,4,2-triyl)) tetrabenzoic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>PBPTTBA) and In(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and fully characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), infrared spectroscopy (IR), and elemental analysis (EA). <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> can be used as an efficient adsorbent for the selective removal of organic cationic dyes in <ce:italic>N,N</ce:italic>′-dimethylformamide (DMF) solution. The adsorption capacities of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> toward methylene blue and crystal violet at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K can reach 1119<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg/g and 832<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg/g, respectively. Moreover, the adsorbed dyes can be released in the DMF solution of LiNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> gradually.</ce:simple-para><ce:para id="par0015" view="all">In this work, a tetratopic acid ligand with double Lewis pyridine sites, 4,4′,4″,4′″-(4,4′-(1,4-phenylene)bis(pyridine-6,4,2-triyl)) tetrabenzoic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>PBPTTBA) has been designed and synthesized. The assembly of H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>PBPTTBA with In(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>∙5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in DMF yielded a new anionic MOF, [In(PBPTTBA)][(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>, where BUT<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Beijing University of Technology). <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> can rapidly and selectively adsorb organic cationic dyes including acriflavine hydrochloride (AH), acridine red (AR), safranine O (SO), methylene blue (MB), crystal violet(CV) and rhodamine 6G (R6G) through an ion-exchange process. Organic anionic and neutral dyes such as congo red (CR), orange G, naphthol yellow S (NYS), orange II, acid fuchsin (AF), methyl orange (MO), methyl yellow (MY), tartrazine, and isatin cannot be adsorbed by <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>. Furthermore, adsorption isotherms measured at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K demonstrate that the maximum adsorption amounts of MB and CV in <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> are 1119 and 832<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg/g, respectively, and <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> could be fully reused after washing with DMF solution of LiNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> several times. These results indicate that <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> is promising adsorbents for efficient capture of MB and CV from waste water.</ce:para><ce:para id="par0025" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> crystallizes in an orthorhombic chiral space group of <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>. In the structure of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>, the In<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> ion adopts a tetrahedral linkage geometry through coordinating to eight O atoms from four carboxylate groups of four different PBPTTBA<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligands (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig0005"></ce:float-anchor>a). The In-O distances are in the range of 2.2617(1) Å to 2.2905(1) Å, being comparable to those of reported indium complexes . As shown in c, the carboxylate groups in PBPTTBA<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand exhibit chelating coordination mode, with each one coordinates to one In<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> ion. Thus, one In<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> connect to four PBPTTBA<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligands and one PBPTTBA<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand connect to four In<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> atoms to form a 3D framework with one dimensional (1D) rhombic channel, the edge length of which is 16.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (atom to atom distance). Furthermore, two such frameworks are mutually interpenetrated (d). After removal of free solvent molecules, the total solvent-accessible volume of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> is estimated to be 71.3% by <ce:italic>PLATON</ce:italic>. From the topological viewpoint, each In(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> node and PBPTTBA<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand can be viewed as 4-connected nodes, the 3D structure of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> can thus be simplified as a 4,4-c net with the point symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>), corresponding to a <ce:italic>Pts</ce:italic>-type topology. It should be noted that in the framework of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>, every In<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> atom connect with four carboxylic groups, thus, in its pore, there should exist counter-cations to balance the charge of the framework. However, due to the disordered nature, these counter-cations could not be identified through single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. We speculate that these counter-cations should be (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, which is a common by-product in the solvothermal reaction when DMF was used as solvent. EA analysis was then carried out, which showed extra N content inside the pore, which implied the presence of (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>. Furthermore, in the TGA curve of the as-synthesized <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>, there exist a 7.1% weight loss between 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 340<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which is well corresponding to the presence of one (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion per formula (Fig. S1).</ce:para><ce:para id="par0030" view="all">Based on the large rhombic channels and cationic framework of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>, we sought to explore its application in the removal of organic dyes. Fifteen dyes including AH, AR, SO, MB, CV, R6G, CR, orange G, NYS, orange II, AF, MO, MY, Tartrazine, and Isatin were checked. Freshly prepared <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> was well activated and then immersed in DMF solutions of these dyes at room temperature. The adsorption abilities of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> toward these dyes were determined by UV–vis spectroscopy. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig0010"></ce:float-anchor>a–d and Figs. S4 (Supporting information), nearly all the cationic dyes can be removed within 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min, while the anionic and neutral dyes could not be absorbed. To future demonstrate the selective adsorption of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> toward cationic dyes, the MOF samples were soaked in the binary mixtures of MB/MO, MB/RB with the concentration ratio is 50/50, respectively. The results were as expected: only the MB was absorbed by the <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> in the solution mixture and the solutions exhibited the color of MO or RB at last and the color of the <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> changed from yellow to blue (inset photograph of e and f). Moreover, compared to other absorbents using a few days, the absorption rate of cationic dyes by <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> was really fast, and nearly 100% of dye molecules can be absorbed within 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min. The high adsorption rate is attributed to the large size of the cage windows (12.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and negative charged framework.</ce:para><ce:para id="par0040" view="all">In the above experiments, it was showed that MB and CV can be completely adsorbed within 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min and 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min in <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>, respectively (a and c). Thus, we further explored the adsorption isotherms of MB and CV in <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig0020"></ce:float-anchor>a, the maximum adsorption amounts of MB and CV in <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> are 1119 and 832<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg/g, respectively. These values are comparable and even higher than those in other porous materials reported so far (Table S2 in Supporting information). In addition, we further measured the of FT-IR spectra of MB loaded <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> and found the appearance of an extra characteristic peak in the wavenumber of 1323<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, which should be the stretching vibration peak of C-N bond of MB molecules, indicating that MB molecules are indeed adsorbed into the pores of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> (Fig. S5 in Supporting information). The superior performances of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> in MB and CV adsorptions could be ascribed to their large specific surface areas, suitable pore size, as well as the ionic interactions between the cationic dye and anionic framework structure of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>. Moreover, Langmuir  and Freundlich  models were used to fit and examine above adsorption isotherms respectively. The related parameters are given in Figs. S6 and S7 in Supporting information. Obviously, the data are well fitted by the Langmuir model, indicating a homogeneous and monolayer adsorption occurring in <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> with a finite number of identical sites.</ce:para><ce:para id="par0050" view="all">In summary, a new In(III)-based MOF, <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold>, has been designed, synthesized, and used in the selective adsorption of organic cationic dyes in DMF solution. <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> has a 3D framework with one dimensional (1D) rhombic channel, which is occupied by (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> counter ions. <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> can be used as an excellent candidate for the selective adsorption of organic cationic dyes and its maximum adsorption amounts toward MB and CV are 1119<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg/g and 832<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg/g, respectively, comparable or higher than those in other porous materials reported so far. The adsorption isotherms of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> toward MB and CV can be fitted by the Langmuir model, indicating a homogeneous and monolayer adsorption process. In addition, <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> can be fully reused after washing with DMF solution of LiNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> several times.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

An In(III)-based metal-organic framework (BUT-29) can selectively absorb cationic dyes in DMF even in the presence of other organic dyes, and has the higher adsorption capacity.

      

Abstract

In this paper, a new anionic metal-organic framework, [In(PBPTTBA)][(CH3)2NH2] (BUT-29) has been synthesized through the reaction of tetratopic acid ligand with double Lewis pyridine sites, 4,4',4",4‴-(4,4'-(1,4-phenylene)bis(pyridine-6,4,2-triyl)) tetrabenzoic acid (H4PBPTTBA) and In(NO3)2 ⋅5H2O and fully characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), infrared spectroscopy (IR), and elemental analysis (EA). BUT-29 can be used as an efficient adsorbent for the selective removal of organic cationic dyes in N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF) solution. The adsorption capacities of BUT-29 toward methylene blue and crystal violet at 298K can reach 1119mg/g and 832mg/g, respectively. Moreover, the adsorbed dyes can be released in the DMF solution of LiNO3 gradually.

In this work, a tetratopic acid ligand with double Lewis pyridine sites, 4,4',4",4'"-(4,4'-(1,4-phenylene)bis(pyridine-6,4,2-triyl)) tetrabenzoic acid (H4PBPTTBA) has been designed and synthesized. The assembly of H4PBPTTBA with In(NO3)2∙5H2O in DMF yielded a new anionic MOF, [In(PBPTTBA)][(CH3)2NH2] (BUT-29, where BUT=Beijing University of Technology). BUT-29 can rapidly and selectively adsorb organic cationic dyes including acriflavine hydrochloride (AH), acridine red (AR), safranine O (SO), methylene blue (MB), crystal violet(CV) and rhodamine 6G (R6G) through an ion-exchange process. Organic anionic and neutral dyes such as congo red (CR), orange G, naphthol yellow S (NYS), orange II, acid fuchsin (AF), methyl orange (MO), methyl yellow (MY), tartrazine, and isatin cannot be adsorbed by BUT-29. Furthermore, adsorption isotherms measured at 298K demonstrate that the maximum adsorption amounts of MB and CV in BUT-29 are 1119 and 832mg/g, respectively, and BUT-29 could be fully reused after washing with DMF solution of LiNO3 several times. These results indicate that BUT-29 is promising adsorbents for efficient capture of MB and CV from waste water.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals BUT-29 crystallizes in an orthorhombic chiral space group of C2/c. In the structure of BUT-29, the InIII ion adopts a tetrahedral linkage geometry through coordinating to eight O atoms from four carboxylate groups of four different PBPTTBA4- ligands ( a). The In-O distances are in the range of 2.2617(1) Å to 2.2905(1) Å, being comparable to those of reported indium complexes . As shown in c, the carboxylate groups in PBPTTBA4- ligand exhibit chelating coordination mode, with each one coordinates to one InIII ion. Thus, one InIII connect to four PBPTTBA4- ligands and one PBPTTBA4- ligand connect to four InIII atoms to form a 3D framework with one dimensional (1D) rhombic channel, the edge length of which is 16.8Å (atom to atom distance). Furthermore, two such frameworks are mutually interpenetrated (d). After removal of free solvent molecules, the total solvent-accessible volume of BUT-29 is estimated to be 71.3% by PLATON. From the topological viewpoint, each In(COO)4 node and PBPTTBA4- ligand can be viewed as 4-connected nodes, the 3D structure of BUT-29 can thus be simplified as a 4,4-c net with the point symbol of (42 ×84), corresponding to a Pts-type topology. It should be noted that in the framework of BUT-29, every InIII atom connect with four carboxylic groups, thus, in its pore, there should exist counter-cations to balance the charge of the framework. However, due to the disordered nature, these counter-cations could not be identified through single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. We speculate that these counter-cations should be (CH3)2NH2+, which is a common by-product in the solvothermal reaction when DMF was used as solvent. EA analysis was then carried out, which showed extra N content inside the pore, which implied the presence of (CH3)2NH2+. Furthermore, in the TGA curve of the as-synthesized BUT-29, there exist a 7.1% weight loss between 200°C and 340°C, which is well corresponding to the presence of one (CH3)2NH2+ ion per formula (Fig. S1).

Based on the large rhombic channels and cationic framework of BUT-29, we sought to explore its application in the removal of organic dyes. Fifteen dyes including AH, AR, SO, MB, CV, R6G, CR, orange G, NYS, orange II, AF, MO, MY, Tartrazine, and Isatin were checked. Freshly prepared BUT-29 was well activated and then immersed in DMF solutions of these dyes at room temperature. The adsorption abilities of BUT-29 toward these dyes were determined by UV-vis spectroscopy. As shown in  a-d and Figs. S4 (Supporting information), nearly all the cationic dyes can be removed within 15min, while the anionic and neutral dyes could not be absorbed. To future demonstrate the selective adsorption of BUT-29 toward cationic dyes, the MOF samples were soaked in the binary mixtures of MB/MO, MB/RB with the concentration ratio is 50/50, respectively. The results were as expected: only the MB was absorbed by the BUT-29 in the solution mixture and the solutions exhibited the color of MO or RB at last and the color of the BUT-29 changed from yellow to blue (inset photograph of e and f). Moreover, compared to other absorbents using a few days, the absorption rate of cationic dyes by BUT-29 was really fast, and nearly 100% of dye molecules can be absorbed within 10min. The high adsorption rate is attributed to the large size of the cage windows (12.4×7.1Å) and negative charged framework.

In the above experiments, it was showed that MB and CV can be completely adsorbed within 6min and 4min in BUT-29, respectively (a and c). Thus, we further explored the adsorption isotherms of MB and CV in BUT-29 at 298K. As shown in  a, the maximum adsorption amounts of MB and CV in BUT-29 are 1119 and 832mg/g, respectively. These values are comparable and even higher than those in other porous materials reported so far (Table S2 in Supporting information). In addition, we further measured the of FT-IR spectra of MB loaded BUT-29 and found the appearance of an extra characteristic peak in the wavenumber of 1323cm-1, which should be the stretching vibration peak of C-N bond of MB molecules, indicating that MB molecules are indeed adsorbed into the pores of BUT-29 (Fig. S5 in Supporting information). The superior performances of BUT-29 in MB and CV adsorptions could be ascribed to their large specific surface areas, suitable pore size, as well as the ionic interactions between the cationic dye and anionic framework structure of BUT-29. Moreover, Langmuir  and Freundlich  models were used to fit and examine above adsorption isotherms respectively. The related parameters are given in Figs. S6 and S7 in Supporting information. Obviously, the data are well fitted by the Langmuir model, indicating a homogeneous and monolayer adsorption occurring in BUT-29 with a finite number of identical sites.

In summary, a new In(III)-based MOF, BUT-29, has been designed, synthesized, and used in the selective adsorption of organic cationic dyes in DMF solution. BUT-29 has a 3D framework with one dimensional (1D) rhombic channel, which is occupied by (CH3)2NH2 2+ counter ions. BUT-29 can be used as an excellent candidate for the selective adsorption of organic cationic dyes and its maximum adsorption amounts toward MB and CV are 1119mg/g and 832mg/g, respectively, comparable or higher than those in other porous materials reported so far. The adsorption isotherms of BUT-29 toward MB and CV can be fitted by the Langmuir model, indicating a homogeneous and monolayer adsorption process. In addition, BUT-29 can be fully reused after washing with DMF solution of LiNO3 several times.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0005">
<ce:simple-para id="spar0005" view="all">(a) View of the [In(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] node; (b) View of the single open framework in <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> along c axis, showing large rhombic channels (c) coordination mode of the PBPTTBA<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand; (d) View of the 3D framework of <ce:bold>BUT-29</ce:bold> along c axis, showing two-fold interpenetration of the network.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:alt-text id="at0530" role="short">Fig. 1</ce:alt-text>

</ce:figure>
